verses.text: For everything there is a season, and a time for every purpose under heaven:
verses.comment: This verse introduces the poem about the appointed times for all things, reflecting God's providence over creation. The phrase 'under heaven' points to the ordering of life by divine wisdom.

verses.text: A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to uproot what is planted;
verses.comment: Confirms the sovereignty of God over the boundaries of life and death, as well as the cycles of nature. Theological tradition understands this as God's intimate knowledge and governance of every soul.

verses.text: A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up;
verses.comment: These contrasts highlight the fullness of human experiences, echoing themes of judgment and restoration. Healing and rebuilding suggest divine mercy after righteous judgment.

verses.text: A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
verses.comment: Reflects the rhythm of loss and joy. Scriptural references to God turning mourning into dancing suggest hope of redemption and restoration.

verses.text: A time to throw away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
verses.comment: The gathering and scattering of stones can symbolize preparing or destroying places, as well as the wisdom to know when relationships or actions are appropriate.

verses.text: A time to seek, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to throw away;
verses.comment: Expresses the ordering of human desires and possessions, emphasizing detachment from worldly things, a virtue commended in traditional Christian teaching.

verses.text: A time to tear, and a time to mend; a time to be silent, and a time to speak;
verses.comment: The balance of action and restraint is a repeated biblical theme, suggesting wisdom in knowing when to act or hold back, both physically and verbally.

verses.text: A time to love, and a time to hate; a time for war, and a time for peace.
verses.comment: The realities of love and hate reflect the presence of sin and the call to righteousness; ultimately, Scripture looks forward to the peace established by the Messiah.

verses.text: What gain has the worker from his toil?
verses.comment: Echoes the motif of questioning the lasting value of earthly labor, encouraging readers towards seeking meaning beyond temporal achievement.

verses.text: I have seen the burden that God has given to the children of man to be occupied with.
verses.comment: Acknowledges the toil of human life under divine sovereignty, inviting reflection on God’s purpose for suffering and labor.

verses.text: He has made everything beautiful in its time. Also, he has set eternity in the human heart, yet no one can fathom what God has done from beginning to end.
verses.comment: This verse points to innate human longing for the eternal, which finds fulfillment in God's revelation. The beauty of creation and the mystery of God's plans are central themes of the faith, and this echoes mankind’s search for the divine.

verses.text: I perceived that there is nothing better for them than to rejoice and do good as long as they live;
verses.comment: The call to rejoice and pursue virtue echoes the biblical vision of human flourishing when in harmony with God's will.

verses.text: And also that every man should eat and drink and find satisfaction in all his toil—this is the gift of God.
verses.comment: Proper enjoyment of earthly blessings is acknowledged as coming from above. Gratitude for God’s gifts is foundational in spiritual life.

verses.text: I know that whatever God does will endure forever; nothing can be added to it, nor anything taken from it. God has done it, so that men will fear him.
verses.comment: Points to God's unchangeable nature and the enduring quality of His works. The appropriate response is awe and reverence. This anticipates faith in the ultimate completion of God’s will, as spiritual tradition teaches.

verses.text: That which is, already has been; that which is to be, already has been; and God seeks what has been driven away.
verses.comment: Describes the cyclical nature of life and history. God, however, is continually involved, even in what seems lost or forgotten—a subtle reference to divine providence.

verses.text: Moreover, I saw under the sun that in the place of judgment, wickedness was there, and in the place of righteousness, wickedness was there as well.
verses.comment: Highlights injustice, even where justice should prevail. This persistent corruption in the world highlights the need for God's ultimate judgment.

verses.text: I said in my heart, God will judge the righteous and the wicked, for there is a time for every matter and for every work.
verses.comment: Affirms divine retribution at the appointed time. This anticipation of judgment finds fulfillment in the teachings of Christ concerning the final judgment.

verses.text: I said in my heart concerning the children of man that God is testing them to show that they themselves are but beasts.
verses.comment: The humbling reality of human mortality is contrasted with divine perfection. The theme of testing echoes throughout Scripture, reminding believers of the need for grace and transformation.

verses.text: For what happens to the children of man and what happens to the beasts is the same; as one dies, so dies the other. They all have the same breath, and man has no advantage over the beasts, for all is vanity.
verses.comment: Sobering reflection on mortality calls believers to hope beyond earthly existence, looking to the promise of resurrection and eternal life.

verses.text: All go to one place. All are from the dust, and to dust all return.
verses.comment: Links the fate of mankind to the original curse of death. Yet, through Christ, believers are promised restoration from death to life.

verses.text: Who knows whether the spirit of man goes upward and the spirit of the beast goes down into the earth?
verses.comment: Expresses uncertainty about the afterlife. Later biblical revelation brings clarity about the human soul's destiny, encouraging belief in resurrection and the hope of heaven.

verses.text: So I perceived that there is nothing better than that a man should rejoice in his work, for that is his portion. Who can bring him to see what will come after him?
verses.comment: Encourages trust in God while living faithfully, recognizing the mystery of the future. This notion of living in hope and accepting God's provision undergirds Christian spirituality.
